reviewText:
I went to see this film in the theater a few months ago, knowing very little about it, and was absolutely blown away by its inventiveness, cleverness, and vitality.  For some reason it never got a real release here in Boston, and so now it appears on DVD having hardly been in theaters.
But the DVD of this movie is extremely well made and complements the movie well: lots of commentary, and a ton of deleted scenes.  The movie is incredibly mysterious, and the DVD kind of helps to clear up the mystery.
Not only is this movie set in the 80's, but it also has an 80's movie feel: it has a tone that is somewhat remininscent of "repo man", "heathers", with a little "highlander" (?!) thrown in.  the high school slo-mo scene set to the tune of tears for fears' "head over heels" is a classic movie moment.

I was really looking forward to this movie, but so much of it strikes me as a really well made, feature-budgeted student film.
Why?
Because "Donnie Darko" is bursting with inspiration (some fresh, a lot borrowed) and yet it just doesn't seem to have the wisdom of very much actual experience. I was both fascinated and frustrated at every turn and in the end I was mostly just disappointed.
For starters, "DD" is saddled with one of the most opaque and least likeable main characters since "Brewster McCloud" (which comes to mind because it, too, is an intriguing and risky but ultimately unsuccessful experiment). Jake Gyllenhaal plays Donnie with the "head down, eyes up" sad-smile glower of a Kubrick anti-hero. Sometimes Donnie is smart. Sometimes Donnie is dumb. Sometimes Donnie is mean. Sometimes Donnie is cool. Sometimes Donnie is crazy. Which is like most teenages (or even most people) but it becomes problematic when we can never get a rough estimate of how many cards the central character is playing with.
The other characters aren't much help, either. The villains are cardboard and heavy handedly drawn; virtually free of any sort of complexities, they proudly sing the virtues of censorship, psycho-evangelism, and easy answers. Donnie's rebellion against them almost makes it appear that he's taking easy bait.
Everybody else just sort of wanders in and out of the story, and I was really surprised at how ill-used Drew Barrymore, Noah Wylie, Jena Mallone and especially Maggie Gyllenhaal are. They're all very good when it occurs to the script that they should make an appearance, but most of the time the script would rather watch Donnie be kooky.
Finally, there are just too many elements of "DD" that remind me of, or refer to, other stuff. There's the malevolent infomercial guru prancing around on stage and he seems to belong to another movie (say, "Requiem for a Dream" or "Magnolia"). There's the mystical rabbit-like wanderer (probably only a coincidence that "Sexy Beast" has one, too, but what about, say, "Gummo" ?). The troubled wild child in counselling ("Good Will Hunting," "Ordinary People"). When the movie wants to be cheeky, it displays a theater marquee with the "Halloween Double Feature" of "Evil Dead" and "The Last Temptation of Christ" (zing! crash!). And one would think, since Donnie's mother is versed in Stephen King (she's reading "It" when the movie opens), she'd at least have a clue where her story was going.
Based on the amount of deleted scenes on the DVD, and the wealth of information that's covered therein (including a particularly interesting but excised revelation about Donnie's medication) I think this was a movie that lost its way during the editing.  Director Kelly doesn't seem to have any real regrets on the commentary track so I doubt there will be a more coherent "director's cut," but I imagine that a longer version would've filled in some of the blanks that I was left with at the end of the film.
Nevertheless, as a horror movie, "Donnie Darko" does strive for something MUCH more subtle than most of the recent offerings from the horror genre. It does have genuine moments of creepiness and dread. I felt led on and let down by "Donnie Darko," but I'd rather see this creepy failure five times than see another variation on "I Know What You Did Last Summer" which, fortunately, is one movie "Donnie" doesn't emulate.
I'll be interested to see what Richard Kelly does next.

I have seen hundreds upon hundreds of movies throughout my life and Donnie Darko is one of the most original, enthralling pieces of cinema I have ever seen.  Some people might complain that the movie is flawed, but I have to counter with the idea of choice.  This movie lets you choose what it means.
After I watched this spectacular film, I obtained the music from the film, listened to it all night, while pondering and running through all the ideas presented within.  Of all the junky movies out there, this movie deserves to be seen.

This is an incredibly dark, comedic, and somber film that largely lacks in linear narrative, but covers its ground well with a stunningly original plot and quirky, tone-shifting atmosphere.  At any one moment, you could be howling with laughter, staring in disbelief, or form goosebumps from overall creepiness.  The most satisfying fact is that it is all done extraordinarily well, servicing up what is--in my opinion--one of the best build-ups and conclusions I've seen in a film since SEVEN.
The movie is nothing like SEVEN.  It is the story of a 1988 teenager named Donnie Darko.  While at first seeming to have the cliched problems of teen angst and a dysfunctional family, his world slowly opens up to someone with a deep, psychological malfuntion.  He takes commands from a giant rabbit while sleepwalking.  One night, while out talking to this rabbit, he is told that the world is coming to an end in 28 days.  While he is out that evening, a jet engine that fell off an aircraft destroys his room.
That's all I'll say as far as plot, and I only have said that much because it all happens in the first fifteen minutes.  After that is a mystical journey through Donnie's mind.  While serving up a ton of foreshadowing and plot devices (which seem pointless until the film concludes), writer/director Richard Kelly gracefully churns out political satire, comedy, and insightful views on human nature and teenage rebellion.  I was also impressed by how well the characters developed, no matter how small or insignifican their roles seem to be.  They're all important in the overall scope of the film.
Like I said earlier, this movie does lack a linear narrative.  However, I feel that is overshadowed by how well it covers all the issues it presents.  This is a hard thing to do, but it is occasionally done really well (MAGNOLIA, SHORT CUTS).  The conclusion is something that will probably turn this into a bit love/hate film, if you throw things like implausibility and suspension of disbelief.  However, I am a big fan of such things, and I am tired of cash-filled, gutless Hollywood endings which are geared towards profitibility.
This film is risky, but made with some incredibly promising talent.  I, for one, love it for everything it is.

Donnie Darko is one of those rare suprising films that takes all your expectations and throws them in a blender. This whirlwind of teenage 80's schitzo-angst is a treatise on every adolescent "outsider" and their own self-discovery. It takes the idea of justifying ones existence through self-sacrifice and blows it up a hundred-fold to very unique ends.
The acting (aside from Barrymore) is subtle and carried through with great care so as not to burden the audience with the state of being that these suburbanites are burdened with. Donnie himself as the center of the film (and later, the universe) is bit player to his own demise and the careful development of his coming to terms with death is like nothing I've ever seen on film. The script and pacing allow for real empathy especially in his therapy sessions where he uncovers the source of his dilemna. Sure, the film is flawed (again, Barrymore's character and some wierd plot devices) but the ride is one of the most original takes on that awkward point in each of our existences.
Stunning in every way a film should be.

It baffles me how many good reviews I keep reading about this movie.  I saw it for the first time last weekend, and I'm pretty sure it's the WORST thing I've seen in the last 2 years.  It makes the movie Bats look like Citizen Kane.
As much as I can be fond of her, Drew Barrymore and this film seemed to struggle towards the same goal: to appear clever.  This film left me with questions that I don't even want to know the answers to, mainly about the whole time-frame of the picture (how long has this kid been taking medication, how long has he seen this rabbit, what the hell does The Evil Cult of Swayze have to do with anything?).  Maybe I would re-evaluate this film if someone raved about it in an intelligible manner, instead of just saying this Bubble Boy kid is an amazing actor, and it's sooo original.  It just seemed like a tired formula of a misunderstood rebellious teen who is supposed to become martyred in the end.  The era it takes place in is just about as inconsequential as about 8 of the other "sub-plots".  Also, note to the director: Cussing at the dinner table, followed by a little kid repeating it is so well-worn that it's depressing.  All this does is make the American Pie kids howl with laughter.  Oh yeah, and that "Cellar Door" plot device sticks out like an Eric Roberts Academy Award nomination.
If you are looking for something truly psychological that digs its claws into your head, I recommend Barton Fink, The Minus Man, or Straw Dogs.  If you're just looking for a more entertaining movie, that's easy, just see if your local family-owned video store carries Disorderlies, The Garbage Pail Kids Movie, or Night of the Creeps.
It's a shame that a film like Run Ronnie Run gets shelved while this celluloid turd basks in the sunlight of shallow critics.
Of course, this is just my opinion.

Jake Gyllenhaal is unbelievable! Let's hope he stays versatile. This movie takes you where few movies dare to go. I can't give away plot details, but it's very stylized, eerie, menacing and surprisingly complex. Oh, and there is a giant talking bunny. The use of 80s music is excellent. Don't let yourself miss this one becasue it never played in theatres near you.

Sure there's a psychotic looking bunny-rabbit-suit-man with an eerily sweet voice, but that's just a detail; it's all about time-travel and destiny.  It is just so darn good.  It will either make you depressed, happy, or really confused depending how you interpret the film.  Plus there is just some truly classic American humor. See it, love it

The plastic inside the packaging is so cheap, it arrived already cracked and when you have to be comically careful trying to remove the disc. When I did a piece at the bottom came right off. Don't cut cost on the packaging. We'll pay the extra cost so we don't  have to feel like we're performing surgery just to remove a blu-ray disc.

Didn't in anyway come with the directors cut, but has the deleted scenes (still not the full directors cut). I had mistakenly thought it was the directors cut, but everything is here and it's all great. One of my prized possessions, as it is my favorite movie of all time.
Great movie!
Great Movie!

If you love Donnie Darko as much as I do, I can't recommend this 4-disc blu-ray/dvd box set from Arrow Video enough. The glorious packaging aside, there is so much information to obtain from this stellar release regarding the film and philosophy behind the story that you would be doing a huge disservice to yourself by passing it up (if, of course, you love this film). It's a limited release (and I can't imagine a better one in the future) so get it before the price goes crazy high. Cheers!
Very good low light quality with the 4K scan, which is 50+% of the movie. I framed the included poster. If you like this movie as much as I do, you will buy this, & it is totally worth it!

This set is amazing for Donnie Darko fans. I bought this for my husband to replace our original disc that was never returned after being loaned out. Beautiful images and awesome insight into all things relating to the movie.
One of the best sets I've seen.
Classic movie, still love watching it from time to time
If you love Donnie Darko and are willing to spend a bit more money than the normal Blu-Ray then... BUY. THIS. NOW!
Need to see it a few times to really understand it.
It's good.
The disc case in supreme quality, however the plastic casing did not. there was a crack all down the front, so I just replaced the casing with another.

I received this as a Christmas present and it amazed me at how much detail was put into this. There is a beautiful art and theme that was put into all the art work, cases, books, and cover. I'm very impressed with the quality. The theme was perfect for this cult classic.
One of my favorite movies of all time.
Really really nice. I wish it came with a digital copy though.
Great cult classic!
Love the director's cut.
DVD was in good condition. The plastic cover for the DVD itself was slightly roughened up, but I bought a used copy so it's to be expected.

I'll keep this brief. The movie is excellent. The packaging for this 4-disc set is terrific. The bonus features are copious, although most of them are from the Fox Blu-ray (there is a new documentary that is decent). But, are the picture and sound greatly improved over the previous release? Barely. The sound is identical, and the picture is slightly - SLIGHTLY - better. If you already own the Fox Blu-ray, it isn't worth the upgrade unless you can get a very good deal (I got mine for $12). 5 stars for the movie, but the 3 stars are for the set itself when compared to the Fox release.
Just watch it
Strange weird movie

Great movie.  Why four stars?  I can explain in a name: Drew Barrymore.  Worst rendition of an actress playing a teacher I have EVER SEEN!  It's pathetic.  She literally comes across as a young person, trying to act the way they think a teacher would act ... which obviously is otherwise known as terrible acting.

If you're watching a movie or tv show, and the actor or actress' performance jumps out at you as pathetic or irritating, because you can immediately tell that he or she is acting in a way that a REAL PERSON would not act, ... well, that's crappy acting.  The end.  Drew Barrymore's performance is so ridiculously pathetic, so forced and contrived, I am left with but one alternative.  To deduct a star from an otherwise flawless movie.

Thank goodness she only plays the teacher.

DVD did not play on any blurry player!
I mean come on. It's freaking Donnie Darko.
Great quality. No scratches or anything. Happy to own my favorite movie again.
Great!

This is a great version of Donnie Darko. It is a little easier to understand the plot from this version. Only thing I would criticize is there is no digital copy with any of the different disc versions. That would be a nice thing to have.

I love Donnie Darko, this edition has an excellent presentation (it is a boxed set) so why only 4 stars? because they are going to make me buy the 4k release sometime soon, after having it in all possible formats up to this one. if you have not discover D.D. .. What are you waiting for?

is this review about the movie or about the presentation? this movie is astonishingly amazing.  the box set gets a B plus.

Maybe other viewers were able to understand this movie, but for me it was just nonsense. Nothing seemed to fit together. I have no idea what the writers or director were thinking when creating this mess.

The director's cut ONLY has the versions where the directors are talking over the entire movie and the menu/settings does not have an option for movie only without the blabbering. I cannot for the life of me find a regular unadulterated Donnie Darko. =(
Amazing boxed set!!!!!! Donnie darko gets the treatment it finally deserves. A wealth of extras and features rounds out this amazing set, if your a fan it's a must own.

Occasionally there comes along a special edition DVD that is so cool, it makes the movie watching experience even better. Memento is one example, Donnie Darko is another. The art cards, poster, envelope, book, and DVD content make this well worth the price.
If you are a fan of Donnie Darko, you should definitely check this out.
Good movie
Just as listed. Perfect.

Donnie Darko (2001) is a most unusual film with a fantastic musical score; but it's the plot that makes this a one-of-a-kind masterpiece. Yes, this isn't straight up sci-fi with nothing but special effects; it's about a troubled teen and the emotional turmoil he's in, all the while answering to an imaginary friend. Time travel is central to the plot, and twists appear throughout. What makes this an absorbing film is in how it makes the viewer wonder what will happen next, and to their astonishment, it most likely isn't what the viewer visualized. I don't want to spoil the plot, but it's a film that'll reward the viewer that sticks with it. This film also has a lot of humor. Donnie Darko touches on emotions, and is a feel-good kind of movie overall. The script is well-written, and there are memorable lines. And with a believable musical score, it all adds up to an unforgettable experience. I highly recommend the Director's Cut over the theatrical version, though the latter is pretty good as well. The blu ray is a good print, with very good picture and sound quality, with special features that beg for viewing, as I wanted to know about the evolution of this remarkable film. If you're looking for something very unique, then Donnie Darko is for you.
This is one of the nicest Blu Ray sets I've ever seen!  Seriously in love with it.
Excellent!
Really Excellent Set.  Very pleased with this product.  Good transfer of the films and lots of extras.  The definitive presentation of this film
gift

Thirty extra minutes that the studio insisted that the director, Richard Kelly, remove for the sake of run-time. That thirty minutes makes a huge difference. Though the theatrical release was interesting and intriguing, it didn't make a whole lot of sense. This release explains all of the unanswered questions that the initial release did not. I highly recommend this.

The second disc is almost extraneous though.
One of my all time Favourite movies

Such an amazing box set with tons of digital and physical extras. This is a dream-come-true set for any movie, and is more so the treatment you'd see for a box set like Lord of the Rings, let alone for a single movie. Arrow went above and beyond for this release, absolutely must have for fans of the film

I've seen the movie twice. It was both very confusing and intriguing, clearly only meant for those fascinated by a diverse combination of cosmology, spirituality, relativity, space/time and mathematics. Would like to see how these all fit together in a manner that was better connected, but how? If it hasn't already, this fascinating jumble of ideas will become a cult classic. Maybe one day I will be able to understand the plot better.
Absolutely horrible. The case was battered and the discs were mangled. I am sending this back as soon as I can.
What can you say about this masterpiece??  Absolutely FANTASTIC!!  The entire cast is PERFECT!!

This set is phenomenal. The only bluray set I own that has anywhere near this quality is the Alien Anthology. I mean, the original anthology with the hella thick card stock, not that cheapo version they sell now. And much like Alien, this set is underpriced for the quality you get. A measily $29. I'm about 5 movies into collecting Arrow Video and I didn't think anything could be nicer than Scream Factory releases but I think Arrow might just be. I do not mind throwing money at quality releases. I understand bonus features aren't for everyone, but they are for this guy! This set contains Theatrical & Directors cuts along with 2 discs of bonus material. If you are in the market for this set I'm sure you know what a great movie this is so...

Back in 2001, I watched a movie that stuck with me for years. That film was Donnie Darko. A time travelling sci-fi flick with elements of comedy, drama and horror. (Oddly enough, Donnie Darko director Richard Kelly also directed one of the worst films I have ever seen (Southland Tales).)

The reason Donnie Darko stuck with me and not Southland Tales, is that it was a fantastic film that left you with a lot of questions and just when you think you had the movie figured out, another question will pop up. Most of these questions have been answered in the Directors Cut release, which until this review, I never did see.

From what Ive read online, there seems to be a divided fan base on which version they prefer. Some prefer the more open-ended Theatrical release and others like the Directors Cut due to it making the film a bit easier to follow, yet still leaving a lot of questions up in the air. Honestly, either Cut is brilliant.

I don't want to go into the specifics of the story for Donnie Darko as I feel it has already been dissected and discussed by several other smarter people than me, so I have nothing to add. My unpaid job is to tell you whether you should see it/buy it or not and that I can quickly answer with a resounding YES!

Be it the intriguing story, the acting or the amazing soundtrack that propels the film forward, with some great songs that make certain scenes all the more better, everything is top notch in Donnie Darko. Who can forget the school scene with Head over Heels by Tears for Fears playing or the ending with Mad World blaring through your speakers? Its all interesting stuff that sticks with you.

As for the downside of my review, I cant think of anything negative to say about Donnie Darko. Anything I could think up (say some shoddy CGI for example) is extreme nitpicking and this movie doesnt deserve that type of critiquing (Southland Tales on the other hand? Ugh). What it does deserve is to be watched over and over again.

There are a bunch of different copies of the film out there to watch it on, but throw all of those away as Arrow Video has provided the end all be all release. I cant stress enough how fantastic this box set is; I want to make sweet love to it. Coming in a hard box, with two digipacks, one that houses the theatrical on Blu-ray and DVD, another that has the Directors on Blu-ray/DVD and finally a book with essays and interviews. Each digipack also has a treat in store for the buyer. The theatrical has the poster, and the Directors Cut has an envelope filled with postcards featuring Donnie Darko artwork. Thats just the physical features, but what about the digital features.

The newest feature and the one that everyone will want to check out is the new feature-length documentary on the theatrical disc. Coming in an 1 hour and 25 minutes, Deus Ex Machina  The Philosophy of Donnie Darko features interviews with cast and crew providing a lot of details on the production. The rest of the special features have been available on previous releases, but having it all in one package is a truly "cellar door" thing.

As for the video transfer, Arrow Video provides a new 4K scan of the original 35mm camera negative, along with a scan of the 35mm digital intermediate element for the sections that are unique to the Directors Cut. Each cut has the film looking the best it has ever looked, keeping true to the overall look of the movie. Viewers may baulk at some of the heavy grain and lack of sharpness in certain scenes, but to me, this is how the movie was meant to look, and for that, Arrow Video has succeeded wonderfully. The same can be said for the DTS-HD Master Audio 5.1 mix, which has some fun with the rear channels whenever Frank pops up onscreen.

Even if you own Donnie Darko on previous versions, you still should buy the Donnie Darko set from Arrow Video. It is that great of a release. The work that was put into making this set look as amazing as it is, can be felt throughout every aspect of the box set. Donnie Darko is a film that will stick with you for many, many years and this Blu-ray release will stay front and centre in your collection for many more years.
If you love this weird little movie...this set is the only way to go.

DONNIE DARKO has been one of my all-time favorites since I rented it at 11 years old the day it came out on VHS/DVD. I still remember the morning waiting for Hollywood video to open so I could be the first one in to rent it. Since then I've watched it countless times and it never ceases to amaze me. The atmosphere, the performances from the entire cast regardless of the size of their role, that soundtrack (both Michael Andrews original work, and the song choices), the mind-melting storytelling, and above all, the affecting poignancy. Donnie Darko has it all, a true modern classic of both independent filmmaking and cinema in general, and to date Richard Kelly's best film.

With that said, Donnie Darko for years has lacked the proper bluray release it deserves. The previous american bluray transfer was sorely lacking, to say the least, and it seemed no care was put into the audio and picture quality whatsoever. It was only a slight improvement over the DVD, and so I never went ahead and purchased it, hoping that someday a better quality package would be released.

Thanks to Arrow Video, my prayers have been answered. This limited edition four disc set is ESSENTIAL to all Donnie Darko fans, and is exactly what we've been waiting for. Firstly, the box set is gorgeous, as are the supplements. There's an informative booklet, as well as two digipacks- one for the theatrical cut, another for the directors cut- within those are a double sided Donnie Darko poster (one side is the poster for the theatrical release, the flipside matches the box set's cover), and an envelope appearing to be handwritten by Donnie to Roberta Sparrow. Inside are a collection of various post-card sized artwork. The digipacks themselves also have gorgeous covers that perfectly represent the atmosphere of the film and are nice to have in the collection.

However, as great as the packaging is, it would all be for nothing had the actual film's look been once again neglected. With great relief it can be said that this is the best the film has ever looked on home video. Thanks to a new 4k restoration approved by director Kelly, the film looks noticeably better. While it still has that intentionally hazy quality to it, the detail is sharp and clear, the grain is finely retained, the colors are appropriately saturated. There really is not one flaw I noticed while watching (and this is going for the preferred theatrical cut, as I have not revisited the director's cut yet). I can't state enough how great the film looks now, it's like watching it with a fresh pair of eyes.

The special features also don't disappoint, filled with interviews, several commentaries including the cast, crew, and writer/director, as well as a lengthy documentary exploring the genesis of the film, the making of it, leading to its release, and finally it's enduring cult legacy over the years. Plus the same special features from previous dvd/blurays have been carried over.

In short, if you love Donnie Darko this is a MUST OWN package that was long overdue, but I'm so very pleased to finally have it in my collection. Thank you to everyone involved in the process of making this special edition, and to the filmmaker himself for a film I'll never stop loving.

I will start by saying this movie is absolutely amazing. The extras included in this set are a great touch as well, including a poster, some art cards and a very nice book. Although my set did not come in the greatest condition. The slip cover box was dented on the top corners and the 2 movie cases and the book had dents on the corners as well and even creases down the spine of each one. My review is 5 stars simply for the movie and collection itself, not the actual condition as I don't feel I should dock the rating due to that. I guess I can't complain for the price that it is currently at right now.

It's safe to say that pandering to '80s nostalgia has gone mainstream.  Everything from TV shows (The Goldbergs) to streaming events (Stranger Things) to pizza commercials (Ferris Buehler lived in Chicago, people, he would never order from Dominos!) is coated with day-glo residue of pop culture references and one-hit wonders.  Released in 2001, well before the retro resurgence was even due to arrive, Donnie Darko uses the '80s as a colorful backdrop for its story of a troubled teen on the edge of full-blown paranoid schizophrenia...who also holds the fate of the world in his hands.

 Or not.

The beauty of director Richard Kelly's film is that it doesn't hand out easy answers for its interconnected theories of time travel, spiritual plans, invisible friends and intangible jellyfish sprouting out of everyone's chest.  It's a sort of sci-fi-afterschool-special that manages to treat mental illness with some real emotional weight and also get a laugh or two.

Set in a Castle Rock-style suburbia full of quirky neighbors and oddball students, the Darko family is an island of sanity in a world gone mad.  Yet, ironically, middle child Donnie (Jake Gyllenhaal) is emotionally unbalanced and socially awkward.  Things only get worse when visions of a costumed rabbit (named Frank) interrupt his sleep, warning him of a 28-day countdown until the end of the world.  The new girl in school (Jena Malone) provides some romantic distraction, but even her fate seems wrapped up in Donnie's theory of impending disaster.  Is he hooked into some metaphysical information pipeline...or merely an imaginative psychotic break?

Premiering at Sundance, Donnie Darko brings along a lot of hipster indie baggage.  Drew Barrymore (also an executive producer on the film) plays a too-cool-for-school English teacher who gets sacked for challenging her students while slow motion scenes play out to alternative hits from the likes Echo & The Bunnymen and Tears for Fears, interrupting the action like a Greek chorus.  Even the Smurfs get name-dropped.  But Kelly only uses these elements as decoration.  Underneath it all is the disturbingly tragic profile Donnie's broken mind and its effect on world around him.

Kelly, making his feature-directing debut, shoots with a confidence he never quite recaptured in subsequent films.  And he lucks into a real humdinger of a cast, including Gyllenhaal, his sister Maggie, Patrick Swayze, Noah Wyle and a handful of before-they-were-stars bit players.  As good as Gyllenhaal is - and he's very good - it's Mary McDonnell as Donnie's mother who delivers some of the most heartbreaking scenes, torn between her unconditional love for her son while recognizing the danger he poses to himself and others.

Donnie Darko is an addictively puzzling film.  And Arrow Films new Blu-ray / DVD limited edition revisits it with a brand-new 4K transfer and gobs of extras to help you dig deeper.  It starts with the usual trailers, TV spots, storyboards and archive featurettes (mostly carried over from previous editions) then gets real with the Deus Ex Machina documentary, production diaries, more archive interviews from cast and crew, three full audio commentaries, B-roll footage, twenty deleted and alternate scenes (with Kelly commentary) plus Kelly's 1996 short film, The Goodbye Place.  Spread across 4-discs, the biggest perk is still probably having the theatrical and director's cut (which adds close to 30-minutes) in the same set with a spiffy new restoration.  If you snatch it up quick you also get a collectible book with in-depth interviews, stills and promotional material.

This is an amazing set celebrating a truly unique and remarkable film. The 4k restoration rings clear in sound and picture. This set is absolutely loaded with extras which are quite informative and simply wonderful to have if you're a fan of the film. There's an envelope included addressed to Grandma death featuring art cards of the newly commissioned artwork for this set.

The set comes with an incredible hardbound book featuring insights and writing on the film as well as a truly in-depth interview with the director and an introduction by Jake Gyllenhaal. I never knew there was a Donnie Darko book... But there are parts of that book reprinted for this set.

Once again Arrow has killed it with another spectacular and complete / definitive special collectors edition. If you're a fan of Donnie Darko then this is a must have... Otherwise I doubt your commitment to Sparkle Motion.

The Donnie Darko (4-Disc Limited Edition) is an amazing example of how a limited edition should be executed. Arrow video has outdone themselves.

I did not see an unboxing video before buying and I was blown away when I received the box. It really feels like a bargain at $31. The artwork done throughout by Candice Tripp is awesome. The included 90 page book is very well done and I found all of it interesting. I have not read the 2001 Donnie Darko book which the long interview was from and I really found it to be quite compelling. The post cards included with the Directors Cut and poster with the Theatrical Cut are both done well. The amount of special features and extras included is very impressive. I have watched some of them and I'm looking forward to watching the rest. There is material here that has not been released before.

The video quality of the special edition is impressive and a huge improvement over prior Blu-rays. Critics that have reviewed the Blu-rays are also very impressed. The difference for me is more obvious in outside scenes. Overall it offers better clarity and it is a bit darker. The Blu-ray appears very film like and shows details that I have never noticed before. Shadows and dark areas are handled very well and look great. This is not a Blu-ray to show off your home theater with. Look for more recent titles shot digitally. This is an older low budget movie shot with 800 ASA stock. The 800 ASA film was used so that film could be shot with less light. 800 ASA film has more grain and grain is apparent on these Blu-rays but it is not distracting. Bottom line is that this is the best this movie has ever looked and likely the best it will ever look. Arrow Video did a top notch job with their restoration.

Sound is very good and I cannot tell a difference from earlier Blu-rays.

This is a fantastic Limited Edition and well worth the money. For people that have bought the earlier editions and others that have not seen the film this is highly recommended.

To tell you what this film is about would be doing you a disservice. I wish i could experience Donnie Darko for the first time again, thats how enjoyable it is. There really isn't much else like it. Its difficult to apply any one genre to this film.

The arrow release is the definitive edition. Top notch video, audio, supplements, and packaging. Highly recommended.

Here's what u get: a booket, a double sided poster, both cuts on blu ray and DVD, a few art cards, and that's about it on the box set it's really cool and the blu ray has never looked as good as it is now so don't get the 2 disc blu ray get the box set it's worth it check it out and plus there's new featurettes so you'll spend a few hours checking out cool bonus content really worth it

Outrageous letdown for the price.  I bought the BD release in 2009 and was expecting a massive upgrade to the video quality given this release is touting a 4K scan.  BS.  The improved video quality is marginal at best.  Not worth even near the cost.  I'm running this on an Oppo BDP-103D through a Denon 3313CI receiver and shown on a last-generation Panasonic plasma.  Not audio/videophile quality but well above entry level.

Utterly disappointed.  I've seen remasters like An American Werewolf in London and Patton where the remaster was an obvious upgrade.  This is NOT.  Grain is ridiculously overbearing.  Color is muted and pale.  Same as the 2009 print with a marginal upgrade.

Audio continues to be outrageously good.  The DTS HS-Master soundtrack plays nutzo on my Martin Logans and Boston Acoustics surrounds with my massive Paradigm sub.

Overall, not nearly worth the upgrade price.  A terrific movie, but still way short of a reference disc.

Before I delve into this, I should probably come clean. I did not enjoy or understand a whole lot of what was going on with "Donnie Darko" throughout my initial viewing two years ago. To put it more bluntly, my first reaction was, "what the heck did I just watch?" But this is not the sort of movie, I've lately realized, that one goes into without the intent of applying the proper train of thought.

Let's just say I wasn't so quick to write everything off this time. I decided to give "Donnie Darko" another chance recently and came away with a far different and decisively more appreciative opinion of the intricately layered story it was trying to tell. Certain movies have a way of doing that to me every now and again.

Writer and Director Richard Kelly is somebody whose future endeavors I will almost certainly continue to anticipate with much enthusiasm. And Jake Gyllenhaal, it has to be said, is a remarkable standout among a rich and talented cast of great actors. He plays the exceptionally troubled young man of the title with a brilliant intellect and a vast imagination, struggling with the boredom of standard education and a society that is very apparently afraid of its own shadow (e.g. contemporary America). His imaginary friend, "Frank," a six foot tall metal-headed skull-faced demon-rabbit, saves his life by removing him from the the scene of a catastrophe mere moments before it occurs, only to lead him down an alternate path to a far more bleaker oblivion complete with forecasts of doom, psychiatrists, and self-help charlatans.

This film feels as creepy as any well-made ghost story I have ever seen in my entire life, yet redefines the genre of supernatural storytelling in a very unique and original way.

"Donnie Darko" is...at its core...a film about heroism and sacrifice, peppered with disturbing imagery, the horrors of everyday life, and a soundtrack reminiscent of something you'd find within the confines of a David Lynch film; I was particularly intrigued by the usage of "Head Over Heels" by "Tears For Fears," a long-standing personal favorite of mine. It is clearly a film worthy of several viewings, a fact that I myself have only recently come to recognize, and at least as many varied interpretations.

That being said, I still cannot honestly recommend it to just any casual movie buff....especially those who attend films for the pure sake of entertainment. Nor could I ever suggest it to people who need straightforward spoon-fed answers or who have limited attention spans. This is art, and does not need to provide pat explanations for itself. As uniquely interesting as some may find this film, it does have an unrelenting and merciless dark side to it that might very well disturb even the most veteran indy film curmudgeon.

But make no mistake when I say, this IS an overall great and complex film. See it by any means necessary.

Donnie Darko is a look into the mind of a troubled teenager. At dawn, along a remote mountain road, a teenage boy named Donnie (Jake Gyllenhaal) awakens next to his bicycle, surprised to find himself where he is, and maybe pleased to discover hes still alive. After peddling home, he finds his family engaged in an argument incited by his Harvard-bound sister when she announces her preference for a political candidate.

Donnie is in therapy, prone to sleepwalking, and has an imaginary friend  a six-foot rabbit named Frank, who tells him the world is going to end in just over 28 days. During that time, Donnie narrowly avoids death when a plummeting jet engine crashes through his bedroom. He becomes a sort of celebrity at school because of this, but a series of crises occurs  the flooding of the school, an axe in the head of the schools mascot statue, and Donnies English teacher (Drew Barrymore) getting into trouble for assigning a controversial book to her class.

The film has a stylish look and, like Catcher in the Rye, focuses on a young, rebellious character yearning to express himself in society. Gyllenhaal infuses Donnie with a wry sense of humor and grounds the movie in the here-and-now. His Donnie is a regular kid balancing daily life as a teenager with the doomsday pronouncements of his imaginary pal.

The supporting cast includes Jena Malone, Maggie Gyllenhaal, Mary McDonnell, Patrick Swayze, Katherine Ross, Seth Rogan, and Noah Wyle. The soundtrack consists of 80s classics by Echo and the Bunnymen, Tears For Fears, and Duran Duran.

Bonus features on the unrated, widescreen 4-disc Blu-ray + DVD box set include both the theatrical and directors cut of the movie; three archive featurettes; storyboard comparisons; the music video Mad World by Gary Jules; archive interviews with director Richard Kelly, actors Jake Gyllenhaal, Jena Malone, Drew Barrymore, James Duval, Maggie Gyllenhaal, Holmes Osborne, Noah Wyle and Katherine Ross; 20 deleted and alternate scenes;  The Goodbye Place, Kellys 1996 short film; The Donnie Darko Production Diary; galleries; trailers; TV spots; limited edition packaging featuring new artwork; and a collectors book containing an in-depth interview with Richard Kelly, introduction by Jake Gyllenhaal, original stills and promotional material.

Released in 2001 and written/directed by Richard Kelly, Donnie Darko is a drama/fantasy starring Jake Gyllenhaal as a troubled California teen dogged by apparitions of a man in an evil rabbit suit who manipulates him to commit several crimes, after he narrowly escapes a peculiar accident concerning a jet engine falling from the sky. Maggie Gyllenhaal plays his sister, Holmes Osborne & Mary McDonnell his parents, Drew Barrymore his teacher, Katharine Ross his therapist, Jena Malone his girlfriend, Noah Wyle his science teacher and Patrick Swayze a self-help guru. Patience Cleveland is on hand as Grandma Death.

While the movie flopped at the box office, it has since become a serious cult hit. I saw it recently for the first time and went into it cold without knowing anything about the intricacies behind the plot. The only thing I knew was that the kid was harassed by an ee-vil bunny apparition. The film mildly works as a high school drama with a satirical smirk. But the storys just not engaging enough on that level. While the movie has some quality women, it fails to capitalize on their presence (Barrymore, for instance, is barely in it). But Jake is a solid protagonist, even somewhat sympathetic despite the curious things he does.

By the middle of the second act I found myself getting bored with the story and trying to figure out what was going on, but the film perks up in the last act, particularly when it reveals the truth about the scary bunny guy. After viewing, my overall impression was that the story never really took off and was burdened by perplexing ambiguities even while possessing some fascinating elements. I came up with a theory to explain the events (explained below) but, upon reflection, I realized that all the pieces didn't fit. And the movie simply wasn't entertaining enough to bang my head further trying to figure it out. I wouldve given the movie a mediocre 5/10 rating, but after investigating the official meaning and the alternative explanations I had to admit that the film is genius in this respect. It just needed to be attached to a more interesting story with more stimulating characters.

The film runs 113 minutes, which is the version I saw; the Directors Cut runs 20 minutes longer. It was shot in Los Angeles and surrounding areas (Angeles National Forest, Long Beach, Santa Monica, Santa Clarita, Burbank & Calabasas).

GRADE: B-

ADDITIONAL COMMENTARY (*** SPOILER ALERT***Dont read unless youve seen the movie):

My casual interpretation turned out to be one of the alternative explanations of the movie, the so-called Donnie Is Shown the Future explanation, which suggests that Donne is shown the future via the future ghost of Frank and so he sacrifices himself at the end to save everyone. But, as noted above, there are too many holes in this interpretation.

A couple of other popular explanations are the banal Schizophrenia Theory, where the film shows the protagonist going through an episode of his illness, and the Dream Theory, where it was all just a dream, which is too clichd and idiotic to even consider.

The official interpretation I wouldve never pieced together because its just too sci-fi-oriented and complex: Its the Tangent Universe Theory, which suggests that time in the Primary Universe (i.e. reality) is occasionally corrupted and an unstable alternative universe is created, but it will only last a few weeks. Nevertheless, it threatens to destroy the universe. The events you see happening in the bulk of the film are this alternative reality where the universe (or God) is correcting the error to get back to the Primary Universe using an Artifact (the jet engine), The Living Receiver (Jake Gyllenhaal), a Manipulated Dead person (the bunny guy), and so on.  Google it and youll see that the Tangent Universe explanation ties up all the loose ends.

Donnie Darko is a straight up masterpiece. I highly recommend anyone who has only seen it once and didn't care for it that much to give it atleast a couple more viewings. The first time I saw it I thought it was very interesting but wasn't all that impressed especially after how great I heard it was. I've seen it probably 20 more times since then and it's one of my favorite films now. A lot of people seem to prefer the theatrical cut over the director's cut but I highly prefer the director's cut a lot more. Maybe it's because it's the version I've been the most used to. I only watched the theatrical once to just see what the differences were and there's quite a bit. I also prefer the music choices in the director's cut over the theatrical as well. There are actors out there who were born to play certain characters and Jake Gyllenhaal was born to play Donnie Darko (who is not a super hero btw as the title may sound). He is incredible in his performance as he is with most of his performances. He's one of my favorite actors of today. The movie is filled with great cult favorites such as the late, great Patrick Swayze, Noah Wyle, Drew Barrymore and Jena Malone and they are all outstanding. The movie is terrifically dark, intelligent, intriguing, creepy and darkly hilarious. It's also very confusing and pretty much impossible to figure out (which is most of the fun). It's an excellent film that deserves a couple more viewings if you didn't or don't really care for it your first time.

Even if you get it there's going to be a lot of little things that you would never notice.  This show is truly genius and I have NO idea how the person who created it came up with it. Why? And what the F just happened? If you enjoy being confused and making up your own ending, you'll love this flick. If you have any expectation of a rational resolution of the conflicts presented within the film, well then just abandon all hope. Not only is there no resolution, there isn't even any rationality. Now, even in a film about psychosis I would expect than the non-psychotics within the film would resolve it for us. Or even in a science fiction film about time travel and alternate universes, one would expect to learn, by film's end, what the rules of time travel and/or alternate universes might be. Not here. Don't hold your breath expecting to understand what you just saw. I love sci fi. But I want to understand the science. I am open to fantasy films, but would like to know the rules of the fantasy world I'm watching. Don't look for that here. Abandon all hope if you start watching this film.

We watched Donnie Darko for the first time last weekend, Jake Gyllenhaal gives a stunning performance as Donnie. Even his body language--incurving shoulders, questioning eyes, uncertain smiles--reveal a vast, searching intelligence. Mary McDonnell gives yet another in a roster of thoughtful portrayals--this time as the despairing mother of brilliant and troubled Donnie, simultaneously loving and hating him for being emotionally beyond her reach. And Jena Mallone is just wonderful, one of the truest, most authentic young actors around today.
This is filmmaking at its best--an adventure for the mind--not to be missed.

I've read a lot about this movie and seen it on lists of best science fiction movies.  At first I didn't really sympathize with the spoiled upper middle class catholic characters, especially the protagonist.  I was planning to give it 3 stars and call it over rated, with maybe an honorable mention for Drew Barrymore.  Then at the end I got it.  SPOILERS FOLLOW
Here's my take on it.  The point of it all is that all these people, with their flaws and all, would have been better off without Donnie Darko.  When he was saved by Frank the first time all these lives were diverted to darker paths.  So there was a redo, in which Donnie Darko did in fact get smashed by the jet engine.  And all these lives were better.  Still not perfect, but better.  That in itself is troubling.  For most characters it's fine.  For example, the teacher who leads the dance team isn't a perfect person, but letting them have their happiness is harmless enough.  But if Swayze's character is meant to represent a priest, as I suspect, then what does it mean that he lives this life of hypocrisy in which he is privately a kiddie pornographer while pretending to be an inspiring if simplistic pop psych speaker and writer?  Is this a statement about sometimes pedophile priests, and if so is it saying that when they sin they should be allowed to suffer only their inner pain because they're ultimately doing a lot of good?  Or am I reading too much into it?  At any rate, whatever I may think of the message it was well done, the whole buildup with all the misdirection and then this ambiguous punch line.  Not a total let down, worth having watched it, still a tad over rated.

A young Jake Gyllenhaal stars in this 2001 psychological teen thriller as Donnie Darko, a troubled but intelligent high school teen, living in Middlesex, Virginia with his parents and 2 sisters, Samantha and Elizabeth. The film is based off the 80s, taking place around the time of the 1988 Presidential US Election. One night, Donnie is awakened by a mysterious voice and lead out to the front yard where he encounters monstrous, bordering demonic rabbit called Frank eerily informs Donnie that the world will end in 28 days, 6 hours, 42 minutes, and 12 seconds.

He awakes the next morning on a golf course and returns home to find that a plane engine has fallen from the sky and crashed into his bedroom. The strange part is, no one knows where the engine came from and there are no reports or signs of a crashed airplane. Over the next 28 days that'll lead to some sort of doom, Donnie Darko will find out who he is, how to love, what it means to be alive, and ultimately will may discover the key to the universe that could alter time and destiny.

Overall: Donnie Darko is a film that's hard to explain. It's mixed with drama, comedy, creepiness, intensity, laughs, and sadness. It's one of those movies that you can't really describe too much in detail or else you'll give away parts of the flick. What I love about this movie so much is the Donnie Darko character and how relatable he can be to some viewers. He's not just your average teen. Everything about the character is appealing. His intelligence, his frustrations with the world and "the system", his exploration of good and evil, his mental anguish, and so on and so forth. The pace of the film moves at an adequate rate. Not too slow and not too fast, but just at the right pace to keep you buckled in and captivated beginning to end. Watching this at first, this film can be a bit confusing to understand--as I know I was a bit confused and seeking answers about certain things when it was all said and done. But it's completely intentional. I believe the overall point of this movie is for the viewer to use their mind and draw their own conclusions on the premise. I searched for so many questions and answers about Donnie Darko and found numerous philosophical and psychological answers, I was intrigued. Jake Gyllenhaal's performance as Donnie Dark is absolutely astonishing. He takes the role, runs with it, and never looks back. The Donnie Darko character is filled with layers of mystique and he staggeringly unravels each one to perfection. The film is star-studded to say the least. Drew Barrymore appears in the flick as a laid back but dedicated English teacher, Karen Pomeroy. Patrick Swayze also appears as a smug, motivational speaker, Jim Cunningham. Really, everyone who had a part in this movie did an astounding job. But I can't forget about that freakin creepy bunny rabbit! Seriously! It takes a lot to creep me out but that rabbit did the trick (not for kids). Overall, Donnie Darko is an intriguing gem. The plot is gratifying, the acting is on point, and it offers up every emotion and feeling possible from happiness to laughter to sadness and others. It's a movie that stands out by itself and can't be touched. A great for the ages that should be on everyone's to watch list. It'll definitely have you watching it again, that's for sure. Well? What are you waiting for? Go buy it and give this a watch!

Donnie Darko is a science fiction psychological thriller that stars Jake Gyllenhaal in the title role. It depicts the adventures of the title character as he seeks the meaning and significance behind his troubling Doomsday-related visions.

Donnie is a bright and charming high-school student who also has a dark and willfully eccentric side as he does little to mask his contempt for many of his peers and enjoys challenging the authority of the adults around him. He also visited on occasion by Frank, a monstrous six-foot rabbit that only he can see who often urges him to perform dangerous and destructive pranks. Late one night, Frank leads him out of his home to inform him that the world will come to an end in less than a month. Later, the engine of a jet aircraft comes crashing through the ceiling of his room, making him think there might be something to Frank's prophesies after all. The rest of Donnie's world is only marginally less bizarre, as he finds himself dealing with his confused parents, his sister, his perplexed analyst, a rebellious English teacher, a sleazy self-help expert and the new girl at school who is attracted by Donnie's quirks.

This film is a daring, original vision, packed with jarring ideas and intelligence and featuring a remarkable performance from Jake Gyllenhaal. Also,it is an unclassifiable but stunningly original film obliterates the walls between teen comedy, science fiction, family drama, horror, and cultural satire but it remains wildly entertaining throughout. The debut feature of writer-director Richard Kelly is a shattering, hypnotic work that sets its own terms and gambles-- rightfully so, as it turns out that a viewer will stay aboard for the full ride. Also,80's Tears For Fears hit songs such as "Head Over Heels" and "Mad World" are part of the film soundtrack. No wonder it has become a cult classic.

For many years, I had mostly ignored this movie. I had heard about it here and there, but nothing made it stand out in my mind. But the idea that it was a cult classic always stuck in the back of my mind. So one day, I finally bought it. It was one of the best finds I've ever made in movies. For a movie that was made on a shoestring budget, it is incredibly well-written, and Jake Gyllenhaal is perfect in the lead as Donnie Darko. The basic premise of the movie is that Donnie is an outcast teen who can't stand his family, school, or most of his life. One night, he gets a visit from a giant rabbit-looking being named Frank, who tells him that the world is going to end in 28 days and change. Right from the beginning, you're left wondering if Donnie is just schizophrenic or MPD (Multiple Personality Disorder), or if what you see through his eyes is real, and this plot point is used to perfection throughout the entire movie.

Through the rest of the movie, Donnie has to perform certain tasks at the behest of Frank, all of which seem nuts to everyone else around him, but which he doesn't question in the slightest because he comes under the thrall of Frank whenever a new task is presented to him. In between, he finds a girl (Jenna Malone) who in her own way seems to understand him, and they have a sort-of romance. Donnie keeps encountering strange happenings and even stranger characters, and he goes on an obsessive search for what's going on that leads him into darker and darker territory. In the end, he must make a fateful decision (which I will not spoil here).

For anyone who likes a movie that needs several viewings to catch all the small nuances and plot twists, this movie is definitely for you. And the movie itself isn't the only wonderful thing here--even the soundtrack (which features a Gary Jules cover of "Mad World" by Tears For Fears which is actually superior to the original) fits perfectly with the movie. Overall, this is a gem of a movie, and I can now see why so many people over the years have extolled its virtues.

Donnie Darko: The Director's Cut [Blu-ray] This version has both the original theatrical version as well as the director's cut. If you're like me, that's all you wanted to know. This isn't rotten tomatoes, so I'm not going to review the movie.

Due to my burgeoning interest in supernatural/celestial movies, I purchased this dvd of Donnie Darko; The Directors Cut (Two-Disc Special Edition) on February 12, 2015.  As many people know, this movie is about a Virginia teenager named Donnie Darko (Jake Gyllenhaal) who appears to be the only one who is able to see a spirit who has already died and crossed over to another world named Frank (James Duval). Donnie Darko is naturally at first leery of communicating with Frank but starts to trust him a little more after his life is saved from an aircraft crashing in his room. Both his parents Rose and Eddie Darko (played by Mary Mcdonnell and Holmes Osborne) and his siblings Elizabeth and Samantha Darko (played by Maggie Gyllenhaal and Daveigh Chase) care about Donnie Darko in their own way. However, even they are unsure on how to deal with what appears to be insane mind even though Donnie Darkos unconventional communications with Frank allow him to glimpse into the future. Donnie Darkos world brightens a bit when he falls in love with a teenage female named Gretchen Ross (played by Jena Malone) who is a newcomer to the Middlesex Virginia area. There are a number of other multiple famous people featured on this dvd; such as the late Patrick Swayze, Drew Barrymore, Seth Rogen, Ashley Tisdale etc.). However, the ending made me understand why my husband politely told me that it was a good thing that I had my Shania Twain concert dvd and a Strawberry Shortcake movie to watch for cheering me up afterwards. Even then, I would still watch Donnie Darko again (especially since I own the dvd), but I would definitely still have something uplifting to watch afterwards. The following are some of the extras associated with this Donnie Darko movie: dvd is divided up into two dvd discs and would also be of interest to aspiring writers/scriptwriters as well as movie buffs; disc one has audio commentary with writer/director Richard Kelly and Director Kevin Smith, disc two has Donnie Darko production diary (with optional commentary by director of photography Steven Poster), They Made Me Do It Too-The Cult of Donnie Darko, Storyboard to Screen Featurette, and Directors Cut Theatrical Trailer. Last, but not least, there is the feature of The #1 Fan; A Darkomentary; Darryl Donaldson, a Donnie Darko movie fanatic, is shown meeting James Duval (actor who voiced Frank) and meeting various people affiliated with the movie at a San Diego California Comic Con. One more thing; there are various pop culture references in the Donnie Darko film such as; snippets to the song Head Over Heels by Tears For Fears, a homage to Tears For Fears with the feature of The Mad World song and a scene where Donnie Darkos younger sister is part of dance troupe called Sparkle Motion (dancing to the song Notorious by Duran Duran) plus more pop culture references which would probably take up the length of another review.

ive seen this movie many, many times over. it never fails to impress, inspire and entertain.

there are many themes, plots and sub-plots. the characters are off-beat enough to create tonal subtleties that lift up the main plot.

of the themes that can -and should- be discussed i think that the most impressive is "the end of the world". The very phrase conjures up any number of ideas and metaphors. in this case, i feel that "the end of the world" for donnie would have been the series of events that actually came to a head on halloween night at Grandma Death's residence (i'll leave out the details so you can see for yourself). However one detail that i won't leave out is that "the end of the world" would have been the tragic death of his mother. Their relationship is perhaps the most subtle and poignant of all. I believe that she was/is the center of his world, she was the only one that appeared to truly empathize with him, yet was still willing to offer some sort of strict/stern parental guidance for her son. Again, everything that transpired on halloween night, topped by her death would surely have put donnie (already struggling with borderline paranoid schizophrenia) over the edge; in other words it would have been "the end of the world".

THAT'S JUST MY OPINION!!

Having been, apparently, half asleep when I saw this film during its original theatrical run, I was entirely astonished to catch the "Director's Cut" when it played in a revival at Portland's Laurelhurst Theater a few weeks ago (heralded as "one of the five longest runs we've ever had" on the entranceway blurb). The filtering of time and place, character arcs, cultural commentary, neo-metaphysics, hypnosis, cultural commentary (the "VOTE DUKAKIS" message on the refrigerator, after the father's displeased look, is priceless) and too-many-other-things to name is so aptly handled -- so "fitted-together" -- that one feels the well-worn metaphor of a "chinese box" is relevant, here. Jake Gyllenhaal had no reason to doubt himself, after he made this movie (as DeNiro once said, during the making of Taxi Driver [HD]: "We felt we were making something people'd still be watching 20 years later!"); no matter what, THIS one was in the can! WOW! Every turn of the narrative manages to follow a straight path and pack in an additional detour, while getting there. This film is a masterful lesson in how not to overstretch the canvas: little details keep brimming under the surface, making it worth your while to pay attention. On top of that, Richard Kelly has a masterful eye for the way we view cultural figures as icons; hence Noah Wyle as the understanding science teacher and Drew Barrymore as the progressive English teacher come across as neither out-of-place, nor offhandedly sewn into the fabric of the movie, but *deliberately* placed there to play off our intentional-and-otherwise impressions of the people on the screen. Hilarious, heartbreaking, scary, insightful and tragic by turns, "Donnie Darko" is a movie that looms large. Already it's an essential component of its decade, too dense in content and meaning for any one reviewer to plumb the depths of, exhaustively. How did this happen?

This movie is great; don't get me wrong however I also have seen We Need To Talk About Kevin and I thought it was much better and was blown away and deeply moved by it.  Generally I like symbolism and determining what is and isn't real as in The Machinist and American Psycho.  Here, though, the movie is entirely based on the science of time travel and having never first read the book I went into it not knowing this and taking much literally that wasn't happening at all.  By the time the movie ended I was just glad it was over. I thought the portrayal of Donnie Darko was great and that the overall feel of mental illness rang true.  However when I watched We Need To Talk About Kevin I was so mesmerized that I couldn't turn away for a split second.  They are two different types of mental illness, Donnie seemingly harmless to anyone except himself and in fact having a need even to save the rest of the world from evil at least as he sees in these alternate universes whereas in Kevin you have an extremely dangerous teen and the progression that they show beginning when he was so young was fascinating especially because all the actors playing Kevin were so authentic and remarkably seemed like the same person.  I will close again by saying that Donnie Darko, too, was a remarkably believable person however you never got to see the progression of how he came to be that way and I ask please that if you loved this WATCH WE NEED TO TALK ABOUT KEVIN; it may blow your mind like it did mine!!

Donny Darko has become a movie with a cult following.  Many fans say that they relate to Donny not trusting adults, being an outsider and not fitting in, while some say they like "dark" movies.  Many also say that Donny Darko is a movie for intelligent people, which implies that they themselves are intelligent - these same fans often make comments about people who dislike the movie as being "stupid" or "having no active brain cells."  Personally, the people that I would consider "intelligent" understand that tastes in movies are subjective, much like music or food, and would not call anyone names for having different tastes.  There are also a group of fans who love the movie but admit that they don't understand it.

After being disappointed by the movie, I read the literature about this movie and was left even more disappointed.  The movie felt slow paced, the characters and dialogue were dry.  The movie is based on sci-fi concepts that the director created.  Donny is caught in the middle of an event that creates a "Tangent Universe," or parallel reality. He is guided by the "manipulated dead" and "manipulated living" to guide an "Artifact" or object out of the Tangent Universe within 28 days or the Universe may be destroyed.  The manipulated dead are those who have died in the Tangent Universe and must help Donnie in order to prevent their own deaths, while the manipulated living have no idea that they are helping Donny but must do so or they will die.  Donny has been given certain powers to accomplish his task, such as increased strength, telekinesis, control over the elements, and the ability to create wormholes.  However, none of these concepts are explained in the theatrical release of the movie.  Donny is a troubled teen with psychological issues. He spends much of the movie with either a dead, unhappy expression on his face or wears a smirk when he is about to do something mischievous.  Throughout the movie, a person in a giant bunny suit than only Donny can see tells him to do things such as flooding the school or burning down a house.  At the end of the movie, Donny watches the engine come off a plane during a storm and the engine falls into what looks like a tornado or water spout.  Donny actually removes the engine from the plane with his telekinesis and creates a wormhole from water using his powers - of course this again isn't explained or apparent in the movie, as Donny is simply shown sitting on his car observing the events.  Once the jet engine is through the wormhole and removed from the tangent universe, the normal universe is restored, and the last 28 days in the tangent universe are undone.  Donny awakens back in his room where the jet engine falls through the roof and kills him.

A lush, Gothic, teen exploitation film of superior calibre. Donnie (Jake Gyllenhaal) is a typical, upper middle class, cringing dork with anger issues and a friend called Frank, who appears to be a cross between a pooka and Satan Bunny.  Frank informs Donnie that the world only has till the eve of Halloween to live.

Jam-packed with ideas, some of which should lie on the cutting floor: we have surreal visual homages to the paintings of William Blake and John Martin, a soundtrack oddly reminiscent of Badlands, a rock video sequence with (of all things) Tears For Fears songs, Drew Barrymore as an irresponsible teacher of literature, a terrific Jack Palance style turn by Patrick Swayze as a dubious motivational speaker on the subject of controlling fear, Katherine Ross as a mushy Jungian psychologist, a Grandma Death who keeps crazily checking her letterbox, a crippled plane, and a slice of hokum concerning the dynamics and philosophy of time travel.

All in all, good atmospheric fun and worth a few viewings, although I am wracked with doubt over my commitment to Sparkle Motion!

Donnie Darko came out in 2001 & was written and directed by Richard Kelly.
This is a very unique and memorable film.
It's a forward thinking 80s throwback grounded in innovation.
There are very few films that successfully achieve a vintage feel mixed with a more modern philosophical outlook.
Because of this, Donnie Darko was destined for cult classic status from the start.

The soundtrack, the style, the look and feel are all on point.
Aside from the visual presentation there is certainly something more.
Notably, this film marked the arrivals of Jake Gyllenhaal, Maggie Gyllenhaal, and Jena Malone.
Furthermore, in a masterclass of casting, Drew Barrymore and Patrick Swayze are also featured.
This inclusion of 80s icons successfully strengthens the legitimacy of the throwback aesthetic.
You can see Richard Kelly had a vision and he brought it to the screen.

In Spielberg fashion, the film focuses on a family unit in the middle of America.
The center piece of the story revolves around Donnie Darko.
Donnie is a medicated sleep walker troubled by intensive apocalyptic visions.
And that is only the beginning.

A jet engine mysteriously falls out of the sky and smashes mercilessly into the Darko home.
To heighten the paranoia, no airline is reporting that an engine is missing from one of its jets.
Where did the engine come from? It had to come from somewhere.

This inexplicable occurrence is the basis for Donnie's increasingly complex & disturbing visions of mass destruction.
In a quest for understanding, Donnie converses with his therapist, questions the science teacher, listens to Joy Division, & celebrates halloween.
All of these activities contribute to Donnie's potential grasp on the very complex structure of time and space.

Donnie reads The Philosophy of Time Travel, written by Roberta Sparrow, in an attempt to figure this puzzle out.
The searching leads Donnie further down the rabbit hole. What does it all mean?
Yes, there are a number of questions. Some are answerable and some, not so much.

Donnie Darko's ability to transcend cultural eras could be considered time travel in it's own right.
It will take you back, then back further, and then possibly forward.

Overall, a fun thoughtful mental expedition.
As with all great adventures, it's about the journey and not necessarily the destination.
If you appreciate cult films, Darko is required viewing.

After reading a number of reviews about this movie (both the original theatrical release and director's cut) and finding them somewhat mixed, I ordered both versions to judge for myself. Having never seen this film before, I was kind of excited to see what all of the hub-bub was about.

I watched each of these versions twice, and I have to say that I can now understand why some fans prefer one over the other. Without going into detail that would spoil the experience for future viewers, the basic premise of the Donnie Darko story is a conundrum - what is real and what is the product of a troubled or disturbed mind, and how would one ever prove either without any tangible evidence? It's much like proving the existence of God, which is addressed and plays a part in the plot, as is the concept of metaphorical irony.

In short, the original cut offers a more thought-provoking experience for the viewer by omitting certain details included in the director's cut that seem to tip the delicate balance in one particular direction. However, it also has a few annoying disconnects to references that begged for a little more depth or explanation.

The director's cut, though still quite good, goes a little too far in depth or explanation about certain details that has led some viewers astray from the basic premise of the Donnie Darko story, which is the conundrum. I don't believe that the director intended viewers to "understand" or "solve" it strictly from one perspective or another, but to consider the irony of the human mind - that the very thing on which we totally rely for our perceptions of the world around us as well as our identity can't always be trusted - and how that irony is manifested in all of us to some extent.

As far as the visual and audio qualities of both versions, each offers a unique but pleasurable experience to the viewer. The differences in the musical scores and sound effects between the two versions are few but significant in some scenes, yet don't detract from the main plot of story in any major way. The original cut is faster paced and projects a darker "feel" to the viewer, but lacks some of the cooler technical aspects of the director's cut.

I realize that some of you came here to find a definitive answer to the question about which version is better. However, as disappointing as it may seem, my final opinion is much like the story of Donnie Darko. It's a conundrum.

But whatever you decide, don't use the excuse "They made me do it" (LOL - Just watch the movie and you'll get it).

This a great movie, one of those that will blow you away and have you thinkign about it long after the credits roll. My advice - Just watch the original version and if you have questions, get online and search for the explanation and speculation to your heart's content. I did that and had a rewarding experience.

Donnie Darko is, quite simply, one of the most unique and thought-provoking movies of all time. Originally released just six weeks after 9/11, the film - with its early scene of a jetliner's engine crashing through the roof of a suburban house and its open-ended questions about life and death - initially unsettled many people. On first viewing, you likely will find yourself left with more questions than answers. And therein lies the very goal of the film: to weave a tale that is so multi-faceted that second and third viewings let the viewer into the story that much more.

The role of Donnie Darko is brilliantly acted by Jake Gyllenhaal. He completely transforms himself into the title role of Donnie. His sister (in the movie and in real life) is played by the delightful Maggie Gyllenhaal. The film opens with Donnie being found "asleep" on a golf course. And so the story begins. Patrick Swayze's performance as a self-help guru selling simplistic solutions (think Tony Robbins with a very, very dark side) shows the man's incredible versatility and his ability to commit to a role. Throughout the movie, constantly brilliant dialogue is intertwined with a soundtrack of 80's era pop that sets the scene perfectly. When Frank, the giant rabbit, first appears, what are we to make of him? Is he a medication-induced hallucination? A being from another dimension? Or something else, something running in parallel with Donnie's life? I think part of the answer lies in the exchange between Donnie and Frank: "Why are you wearing that stupid bunny suit?" "Why are you wearing that stupid man suit?"

The Director's Cut restores some critical footage to the film, footage that helps flesh out some aspects of the story while also opening up other avenues for thinking about the story and its meaning. Bonus features include a "Darkomentary" about the cult following the film has garnered, that is quite an interesting watch as well. Donnie Darko is a film that I find myself watching again to look for new clues and theories. It is not everyone's cup of tea, but if you enjoy a movie that encourages thinking in new and interesting ways, Donnie Darko is for you.
